body.p:
I did not write you for the last
two weeks because I preferred to wait un-
til I had something more definite to commu-
nicate that I yet had th opportunity of do-
ing. I brought your project before the Board
of Trustees of our congregation, as promised,
but I regret to say that no action was taken,
as they did not seem to think it practicable,
or that a college would be of any use. But
I do not intend to let the matter drop there.
At the next meeting I shall have it brought
to the vote; and in order to test the temper
of the congregation and enable the trustees
to vote accordingly, I am getting three hun-
dred copies of your letter to me printed, for
distribution, among the contributors to our
Synagogue. I have also attached to it the

concluding paragraph of the leader of the "Record"
which you have kindly sent me. My sister
Mrs. Saml Piza, has already promised me a
subscription of $500 (five hundred) in memory
of her late husband, to open a list with, which
I hope the Board will foster; and tho' I have not yet
seen her, to speak over the matter with, I venture
the opinion that her family would add another
$500. to it, if they thought the success of the un-
dertaking depended on their contribution. I
have also shown your letter to Mr. Henry Ger-
soni, and he promised me to do what he can
for the project, in the papers for which he
writes. He requested me to tell you the same,
and said that you would know that that means
something. He expressed the opinion that if
you don't succeed in what you undertake, it
is because you are too despondent. Excuse me
repeating it: I do it to encourage you. On the
other hand, about ten days ago I also sent a
copy of your letter to J.A. Menken, but as
he happened to get ill at the time, I only got

his reply yesterday, a copy of which I beg to
hand you herewith. I took counsel with him
because tho' he is not at present a worshipper in
an orthodox synagogue, he is a strict observer
of the Sabbath, and he is therefore more likely
to do good to our cause than a nominal or-
thodox who desecrates it. Besides, I know him
to be a friend of yours. But I do not agree
with his views. Therefore I would suggest
that you who have had a college in Philadela
and know that neither that nor the one in
Cincinatti needed as much money as he es-
timates, should write him, to disprove this.
and other fallacies of his, as they seem to me. Of course our own aim in the establishment
of a college is to reach the next generation;
and tho' it would undoubtedly take a long time
to put it on a firm and permanent basis, in
the endeavor to do this, we would unite our own
party and influence others; and there is no reason
in the argument, why we should not commence
on ^ a small scale. If the institutions were once

in existence, we could hope to get endorsements
later to enlarge it. Neither do we expect that the
Sheerit Israel congregation alone could attain
the hoped for result. Our purpose is to unite with
other Israelites all over the country, as pleaded
in the editorial in the "Record"; and it is my opinion
that if we orthodox were as expert and energetic
in availing ourselves of any opportunity afford-
ed us as the reformers are in managing their
affairs, we could capture at the present junc-
ture the aid of may who have hitherto been in-
different and apathetic because the danger
was less apparent. Here then lies the chance
of a reaction which Mr. M. thinks is sure to
come, but which we have no reason to expect
otherwise, for if we allow it to escape us, we
are likely to fall more deeply into the abyss
of ignorance.--And since you have asked me
to counsel you, I would suggest your writing
also to the various ministers mentioned in my last,
and others, laymen as well, who you think might
be serviceable to the cause. I understand that

Dr. Drachman, educated at the expense of the
Emanuel temple has turned out too orthodox
for them, and has consequently accepted a
position in a small congregation in New-
ark, N.J. I believe there are numerous
such congregations all over the land who wd.
not refuse their mite if we had a well-or-
ganized body to reach them. I would not
place all my dependence on large congregations
alone, however apparently influential, but
agitate in the endeavor to make the project
a popular one. And as the Record is, I believe,
hardly seen in N.Y., it might not be out of
place for you to discuss the question also in
the American Hebrew and other organs, persis
sistently. If you fail of success, there can be
no reproach in it. Your memory will live
in having fought for a good cause, and one
day your work will bear fruit.--I would
also thank you to send me some plan of
the proposed institution; based in a measure,
if need be, on that of the former Maimonides

College, and the one at present in Cincinnati, as far
as the pecuniary requirements are concerned,
together with all other details that may suggest
themselves to you, in order that I may be able
to reply intelligently to such remarks as are
contained in Mr Menken's letter. Keep me
also informed, at your convenience, of whatever
action you take, and oblige

Yours respectfully and truly,
David M. Piza

Rev. S. Morais
546 N. 5th St.
Philadelphia.
